structuralFindings.rationale: Disney has a multi-layered AI structure: (1) Disney Research Studios in Zurich (16+ years, fundamental research in visual computing/ML/AI), (2) Office of Technology Enablement led by Jamie Voris (new in 2024, ~100 employees, governance/enablement layer), and (3) distributed AI work in business units (Disney+, Parks, Studios). This is classic hub-and-spoke: central standards and research capability with distributed execution. The $1B OpenAI partnership adds a strategic external partnership layer. Structural orientation because exploration (Research Studios, OTE) and execution (business unit AI) are in distinct organizational units.
structuralFindings.aiTeamStructure: Three distinct AI-related structures: (1) DISNEY RESEARCH STUDIOS - 16+ year old research lab in Zurich, Switzerland with additional locations in Los Angeles and Pittsburgh. Led by Chief Scientist Markus Gross. World-class research in visual computing, machine learning, and AI for filmmaking. Close partnership with ETH Zürich. Research feeds into all Disney film studios (WDAS, Pixar, ILM, Marvel). (2) OFFICE OF TECHNOLOGY ENABLEMENT (OTE) - New unit established November 2024. Led by Jamie Voris (former 14-year CTO of Walt Disney Studios). Reports to Alan Bergman (Co-chairman, Disney Entertainment). Expected to grow to ~100 employees. Mission: establish Disney as 'progressive, innovative, and responsible leader' in AI and Mixed Reality. Does NOT centralize or take over business unit AI projects; instead provides governance, standards, and enablement across Entertainment, ESPN, and Parks. (3) STUDIOLAB - Facility on Walt Disney Studio Lot for exploring cutting-edge tech, with Accenture as founding Innovation Partner.

keyPeople.name: Bob Iger
keyPeople.title: CEO
keyPeople.role: Sets overall AI strategy and vision; secured $1B OpenAI partnership; departing March 2026

keyPeople.name: Josh D'Amaro
keyPeople.title: Chairman, Disney Experiences (incoming CEO March 2026)
keyPeople.role: Will succeed Iger as CEO; already integrating AI tools in Experiences division

keyPeople.name: Jamie Voris
keyPeople.title: Head, Office of Technology Enablement
keyPeople.role: Former 14-year CTO of Walt Disney Studios; now leads AI/XR governance across company; reports to Alan Bergman

keyPeople.name: Alan Bergman
keyPeople.title: Co-chairman, Disney Entertainment
keyPeople.role: Direct supervisor of Office of Technology Enablement

keyPeople.name: Markus Gross
keyPeople.title: Chief Scientist, Disney Research Studios
keyPeople.role: Leads 16+ year research operation in Zurich; oversees visual computing, ML, and AI research

keyPeople.name: Hugh Johnston
keyPeople.title: CFO
keyPeople.role: Articulates financial strategy including AI investments

keyPeople.name: Eddie Drake
keyPeople.title: CTO, Walt Disney Studios
keyPeople.role: Succeeded Voris as Studios CTO when Voris moved to OTE

structuralFindings.investmentSignals: $1 billion equity investment in OpenAI (December 2025) as part of 3-year licensing agreement. Office of Technology Enablement expected to grow to ~100 employees. Disney Research Studios has operated 16+ years with world-class research talent. Technology investments described as 'increasingly central' to growth strategy. Company achieved $10B net profit in FY2025 (+36%) and expects double-digit EPS growth in FY2026.

observableMarkers.reportingStructure: Office of Technology Enablement reports to Alan Bergman (Co-chairman, Disney Entertainment). Disney Research Studios appears to operate semi-independently with Chief Scientist Markus Gross. OTE has 'accountability to all business segments' and partners with leaders across the company.
observableMarkers.resourceAllocation: OTE is a dedicated unit with growth budget to ~100 employees. $1B OpenAI investment is ring-fenced strategic capital. Research Studios has dedicated facility in Zurich with academic partnerships. Not clear if there's a centralized AI budget beyond these structures.
observableMarkers.timeHorizons: Mixed horizons: Disney Research Studios has 16+ year track record and focuses on fundamental research (multi-year horizon). OTE focuses on 'agility, speed, and consistency' (medium-term). OpenAI Sora partnership has 3-year term with immediate FY2026 rollout of short-form content on Disney+ (short-term).
observableMarkers.decisionRights: OTE explicitly does NOT 'take over or centralize' AI projects in business units. Instead provides governance and enablement. Business units retain decision rights on their AI initiatives. This is a coordination/standards model, not a command model.
observableMarkers.metrics: Streaming margin (target 10% in FY2026), engagement (especially with younger users for Sora content), and efficiency gains mentioned. OpenAI partnership framed around consumer engagement, not cost reduction.

quotes.text: This deal does is by giving us the ability to curate what has been basically created by Sora onto Disney Plus is it jump starts our ability to have short form video on Disney Plus.
quotes.speaker: Bob Iger
quotes.context: Explaining the OpenAI Sora partnership during Q1 earnings call

quotes.text: We'd rather participate in the rather dramatic growth, rather than just watching it happen.
quotes.speaker: Bob Iger
quotes.context: Explaining strategic rationale for OpenAI investment

quotes.text: Creativity is the new productivity, and I think you're starting to see that more and more.
quotes.speaker: Bob Iger
quotes.context: Explaining his philosophy on AI and creative work

quotes.text: No human generation has ever stood in the way of technological advance, and we don't intend to try.
quotes.speaker: Bob Iger
quotes.context: Explaining Disney's embrace of AI technology

quotes.text: The reason this company is so special is because of how creative we are, and human beings that are generating that creativity, in my mind, that never gets replaced.
quotes.speaker: Bob Iger
quotes.context: First joint interview with incoming CEO Josh D'Amaro about Disney's AI approach

quotes.text: AI to Bob's point is here, and it's something that we're embracing. You're seeing it's supercharged these creatives in amazing ways.
quotes.speaker: Josh D'Amaro
quotes.context: First joint interview with Iger about Disney's AI approach

quotes.text: Walt Disney himself was a big believer in using technology in the early days to tell better stories. And he thought that technology in the hands of a great storyteller was unbelievably powerful.
quotes.speaker: Bob Iger
quotes.context: Keynote speech at Canva Create event, discussing technology and storytelling

quotes.text: You're never going to get in the way of it. There isn't a generation of human beings that has ever been able to stand the way of technological advancement...What we try to do is embrace the change that technology has created, and use it as the wind behind our backs instead of wind in our faces.
quotes.speaker: Bob Iger
quotes.context: Keynote speech at Canva Create event on embracing technological change

quotes.text: AI may, in fact, be the most powerful technology that our company has ever seen, including its ability to enhance and enable consumers to access, experience and enjoy our entertainment.
quotes.speaker: Bob Iger
quotes.context: Annual shareholder meeting remarks on AI

quotes.text: Given the speed that it is developing, we're taking precautions to make sure of three things: One, that our IP is being protected. That's incredibly important. Second, that our creators are being respected, and last, that our customers are being considered and valued.
quotes.speaker: Bob Iger
quotes.context: Annual shareholder meeting on AI guardrails

quotes.text: It's harder today to tell the story of Tomorrowland...We have AI, which maybe that's even endless in terms of what the future looks like, boundless, I think it just gets harder.
quotes.speaker: Bob Iger
quotes.context: Podcast discussion about AI and the future

sources.name: Wikipedia - Disney Research
sources.notes: Background on Disney Research network: Zurich, LA, Pittsburgh locations. Research areas include computer graphics, vision, robotics, ML.

summary: Disney operates a sophisticated Hybrid/Hub-and-Spoke AI structure with three main layers: (1) Disney Research Studios, a 16+ year fundamental research operation in Zurich led by Chief Scientist Markus Gross, focused on visual computing, ML, and AI for filmmaking; (2) the new Office of Technology Enablement led by Jamie Voris (~100 employees), providing AI/XR governance and enablement across all business segments without centralizing execution; and (3) the $1B OpenAI partnership (December 2025) for Sora integration into Disney+. CEO Bob Iger is extremely vocal about AI as 'the most powerful technology' Disney has seen, framing it as 'wind behind our backs' rather than a threat, while maintaining three guardrails: IP protection, creator respect, and customer value.
openQuestions: What is the budget/headcount for Disney Research Studios?
How does AI work integrate between Research Studios and the new Office of Technology Enablement?
What specific AI capabilities has Disney deployed in Parks/Experiences beyond announced initiatives?
How did SAG-AFTRA AI negotiations shape Disney's structural approach to AI governance?
What is the role of Imagineering in AI development for park experiences?
How will the CEO transition to Josh D'Amaro affect AI strategy and investment levels?
conferenceFindings: No major AI-focused conference presentations found. Iger spoke at Canva Create (May 2024) where he was an investor/board member - discussed technology embracing philosophy. No dedicated Disney AI conference presence identified in tech/AI conference circuit.
